title: 112_hr4211
content: The "American Energy First Act" requires the President to fulfill certain actions before drawing down petroleum from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. This includes assessing the effectiveness of oil shale regulations and making amendments to resource management plans. The President is required to direct relevant agencies to treat final oil shale regulations as meeting all legal requirements and implement them without further administrative action. Amendments to resource management plans are also mandated. The President directs relevant agencies to implement the U.S. Bureau of Land Management Approved Resource Management Plan Amendments for Oil Shale and Tar Sands Resources in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming, satisfying all legal requirements without further administrative action. The regulations in subsection (a) apply to areas covered by the resource management plans amended by the President's directive, without needing additional administrative action. SEC. 4. The President must direct the Secretary of the Interior to conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 216 in the Central Gulf of Mexico within 4 months of this Act. Environmental review requirements are satisfied by existing Impact Statements. SEC. 5. The President must also conduct oil and gas Lease Sale 218 in the Western Gulf of Mexico. The President shall direct the Secretary of the Interior to conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 218 under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act within 8 months of enactment. Environmental Impact Statements from previous plans satisfy the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act. The President will direct the Secretary of the Interior to conduct offshore oil and gas Lease Sale 222 by June 1, 2012. The Environmental Impact Statements from previous plans will fulfill the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act for this lease sale. The President will direct the Secretary of State to approve the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline project, which includes energy-related facilities and land transportation crossings on the US international boundaries. The permit will require compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, as well as measures to prevent adverse environmental impacts. The President will direct the Secretary of State to approve the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline project, ensuring compliance with laws to prevent adverse environmental impacts and historic property disruptions during construction and operation. The final environmental impact statement from August 26, 2011, satisfies all necessary requirements. The construction, operation, and maintenance of the facilities for the Keystone XL pipeline project must align with the Construction Mitigation and Reclamation Plan in the final environmental impact statement issued by the Secretary of State on August 26, 2011, with agreed special conditions. No further Federal environmental review is required. The Keystone XL pipeline project must adhere to special conditions, measures for the Sand Hills region, and stipulations outlined in specific appendices of the final environmental impact statement. The permit approved under subsection (a) for the Keystone XL pipeline requires reconsideration of routing within Nebraska, a review period for potential route alterations, and coordination with the State of Nebraska for necessary data and technical assistance. If the President does not approve the route within Nebraska submitted by the Governor within 10 days, it will be considered approved by law. This section does not change existing processes for securing access to private property for the Keystone XL pipeline. The President must expedite permitting for oil and gas activities on Federal onshore and submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico.
